evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the hist_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim investigation.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim case.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the hist_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: Lack of warning implies communication/coordination breakdown among crew involved in pushback
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or warnings were given and acknowledged
If the lack of warning was due to other factors unrelated to communication breakdown

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The tug instructor explicitly stated that he did not receive any warning from the wingman or headset operator about the impending collision, indicating a communication/coordination breakdown (H8).
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited direct statements about communication quality beyond the lack of warning; no explicit documentation of communication attempts or failures

slot_statements.availability: The mechanical/control failure occurred on Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure is resistant to common defeaters, confirming its validity within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t2_interim on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA's hist_t2_interim phase, indicating a relevant control system malfunction.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure occurred on Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim phase on 12-25.

defeaters: Evidence showing mechanical or control system malfunction on the aircraft during the incident
Reports or data indicating failure in aircraft control systems during the hist_t2_interim phase
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates a mechanical or control failure occurred on Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim phase on 12-25; the evidence describes a pushback incident involving tug operation and aircraft movement beyond the tug release point but does not mention mechanical or control failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the historical time frame 12-25:hist_t2_interim.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25:hist_t2_interim scope.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the historical time frame 12-25:hist_t2_interim.

defeaters: Evidence showing a missing or unclear TRP marking or environmental deficiency during the timeframe
Testimony or inspection reports indicating marking issues on the aircraft or at the site
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or observability of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the specified timeframe; the TRP markings and clearance are described as existing and known (H7, H9), and no deficiency is reported.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is documented and available in the hist_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the hist_t2_interim scope.

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

outcome.uncertainty_source: Assuming the provided history evidence corresponds to the hist_t2_interim dataset and that the dataset is accessible and complete.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim case.

assumptions: The described communication methods and roles correspond to crew resource management concepts
The lack of warnings and insufficient signals indicate a breakdown in coordination
The trainee's limited experience contributed to the communication issues
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and coordination protocols were followed and no breakdown occurred
If the collision was caused solely by mechanical failure or external factors unrelated to crew communication
If the tug instructor or headset operator had clear, effective communication methods that were used properly

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 indicates communication methods were insufficient and no warnings were given before the collision, suggesting coordination breakdown. H2 and H3 show role changes and ongoing communication attempts, but the failure still occurred. H9 shows the trainee was qualified but still involved in the event, supporting human factors issues. These align with known crew resource management failures.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim investigation.

assumptions: The evidence provided sufficiently covers the main alternative causes relevant to communication/coordination breakdown.
defeaters: If new evidence showed overlooked alternative causes for the breakdown, such as equipment failure or unreported crew errors, this would change the assessment.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H9 indicate that communication methods and training were in place and that alternative causes such as lack of awareness or qualification were considered and ruled out, supporting resistance to defeaters for communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence about other potential causes and detailed analysis explicitly ruling out all alternatives

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25:hist_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The TRP marking and environmental cues are the primary means to prevent pushback beyond the safe point; absence of warnings implies marking or environmental deficiencies.
defeaters: If there was evidence of clear, effective, and timely warnings or signals from wingman or headset operator preventing the incident, or if the TRP marking was proven to be highly visible and unambiguous under all conditions.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure is resistant to common defeaters, confirming its validity within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t2_interim on 12-25.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The lack of warnings and continued movement beyond the TRP suggest human factors rather than mechanical failure resistance (H4, H8).

node.statement: The identified procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations within the hist_t2_interim scope.

No other external factors influenced the deviation beyond those described
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or warnings were given preventing the deviation
If alternative causes such as equipment failure were identified
If procedural compliance was confirmed by other crew or observers

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows the procedural deviation was due to a combination of factors including the trainee stopping and handing over control, the instructor resuming pushback but the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, and communication limitations noted by the instructor (H2, H3, H4, H8, H9). No alternative explanations or counterarguments are presented that undermine the identified deviation within the scope.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit counterarguments or alternative explanations in the evidence

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, and H9 confirm crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were physically present and reachable during the operation. H8 indicates communication attempts and visual signals were used but not always effective, supporting presence but some communication limitations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement about physical reachability distances or any crew member being unreachable; assumptions made based on described positions and interactions.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: While communication devices (interphone) were operational (H1) and crew members were qualified and aware of procedures (H9), the lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator (H8) suggests communication was not fully effective or accessible to all crew, indicating partial or impaired availability.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly states all communication devices and channels were fully operational and accessible to all crew members; ambiguity exists about actual accessibility and effectiveness.

No indication of incapacitation is present; the instructor noted no warnings were given by wingman or headset operator (H8), implying they were attentive but communication signals were insufficient.

node.statement: Mechanical control components are free from physical damage or obstruction

defeaters: Evidence showing physical damage or obstruction to mechanical control components would change my mind.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history indicates the presence or absence of physical damage or obstruction to mechanical control components.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs and physical presence records during the incident timeframe

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and available to the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify functionality and availability of radios, intercoms, and other communication equipment during the event

children_spec.statement: Crew members attempted to communicate or coordinate during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Review cockpit voice recordings, crew statements, and other communication logs for evidence of attempts to communicate
